awd_titl_txt: REU Site:   Research Experience for Undergraduates in Genetic and Biochemical Mechanisms of Prokaryotic and Eukaryotic Organisms
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center (LSUHSC), located in New Orleans, LA, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. The program seeks undergraduates from diverse backgrounds who wish to pursue future research careers in the biological sciences. The program prepares students to become proficient in 1.) genetic and biochemical concepts using in vivo and in vitro model organisms; 2.) scientific hard-skills (hypothesis-driven scientific problem solving, methodology, data analysis and interpretation, scientific communication); 3.) workforce soft-skills (time management, teamwork, learning the politics of the workplace, and explaining science to a lay audience); and 4.) networking and career development.  The program will provide one-on-one mentoring with faculty from the LSUHSC Basic Sciences Departments and Centers. Interactive workshops include topics such as resume writing and responsible conduct in research. Sample projects include the study of the proteins responsible for DNA repair, the cell cycle, and signal transduction; the regulation of transcription factors through phosphorylation; genome analysis using bioinformatics; and an analysis of microRNA processing. Student selection is based on academic record, recommendation letters, research interest, and career potential. 

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. As part of the program, students will present their projects to partnering New Orleans area middle and high school science classes while serving as role models to younger generations of potential scientists.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths, and will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://www.medschool.lsuhsc.edu/genetics/reu.aspx or by contacting the PI/Director (Dr. Fern Tsien at fmille@lsuhsc.edu) or the co-directors (Dr. Allison Augustus-Wallace awall1@lsuhsc.edu or Dr. Hamilton Farris HFarri@lsuhsc.edu).

por.por_cntn:
The Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center REU (LSUHSC-REU) Program in New Orleans provided research training to diverse undergraduates for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017-2021. The program is aimed at students interested in graduate school and in researching genetic and biochemical mechanisms. It is imperative for students who are pursuing biological science careers to be proficient in their understanding of genetic and biochemical concepts, hypothesis-driven scientific problem solving, current methodology, data analysis, and scientific communication skills. In addition to these hard skills essential for scientific researchers, we provide training for soft skills that have been documented to be essential to research success: time management, teamwork, how to evaluate the politics of the workplace, how to explain science to a lay audience, and how to overcome adversity in the research community. The interns engaged in scientific hard and soft skills via state-of-the-art methodology, presentations, participation in seminars and interactive workshops, networking activities, and community service/science education to local K-12 students. The program also provides professional development resources to aid in graduate school applications to transition somewhat dependent interns into independent researchers.

Over the past four summers, we accepted 35 undergraduates, two high school students, and one high school teacher. Of the 35 undergraduates, 32 (91%) students were from race/ethnicities which have been historically underrepresented backgrounds in STEM: 16 (46%) self-reported as Black/African American, 13 (37%) as Hispanic/Latino, and three (8%) Native American or Native Hawaiian.  Sixty-three (63%) of the undergraduates were female and 37% male. Supplemental funding allowed for the acceptance of two high school students and one teacher from underserved communities in urban New Orleans, LA. The high school students worked with mentors who had current REU students or REU alumni/graduate students. The teacher is hearing impaired and a science instructor at schools for the deaf through the Louisiana Deafblind Project. She worked in the laboratories and learned concepts and techniques to share with her institution, other teachers in the area, and high school students of diverse backgrounds, from underserved communities, and/or with disabilities in need of science enrichment.

Twenty (20) of the 35 undergraduate interns in 2017-2020 were the first generation college students. Thirty-seven percent (37) % were from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and other institutions in the New Orleans area; the remaining 63% attended HBCUs and other colleges outside of New Orleans, Louisiana.

In 2020, the REU program was conducted via a remote learning model due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The projects focused on investigations utilizing computer-based projects (bioinformatics, protein modeling and cellular imaging) and data analytics. The program culminated in a virtual poster session, where students recorded their poster presentations using Zoom, and met with judges to discuss their projects. A virtual awards ceremony was held via Zoom, and abstracts, posters, and Zoom recordings were displayed in the REU Poster Session website. For community service, the students recorded presentations about their research to non-scientists and K-12 children. Despite the lack of on-campus research and activities, students and mentors readily adapted to the virtual model.

This program to date (since 2014) has yielded a significant number of research products by 66 REU participants, including more than 100 platform and poster presentations at local, national, and international conferences and 35 REU student/alumni co-authored publications. Of the scientific publications, 31 (89%) were co-authored by REU alumni who are of underrepresented backgrounds. Twenty-six of REU alumni have been accepted to graduate programs (21 in PhD and 5 in Master’s); however, many of the alumni are still enrolled in undergraduate institutions. The tracking of REU alumni will determine the long term impact of this program on the local as well as the broader scientific communities, and the effects upon overall diversity in the basic sciences. 

The LSUHSC REU Program has broadened the participation of students from underrepresented/underserved backgrounds within the biological sciences. A diverse group of interns have worked in laboratories, presented at local and national conferences, enrolled in graduate programs, and published manuscripts. Professional development training of students and mentors has fostered an environment of collegiality and open communication. REU interns’ presentations to local K-12 science workshops have been an invaluable experience in which they network, perform community service, and serve as role models to younger generations of potential scientists.
